subject: polity
title: Exceptions and Limitations to Fundamental Rights

rationale: **FRs are NOT absolute** - subject to reasonable restrictions
**Balance individual liberty** with **social welfare** and **public interest**
**Prevent misuse** of FRs for anti-national activities
typesOfExceptions: **6. Saving of certain laws** - Art 31A, 31B, 31C (property, DPSP)
**7. Armed Forces** - Art 33 (Parliament can restrict/abrogate FRs)
content.examTips: **Most asked**: FRs NOT absolute. Reasonable restrictions under Art 19(2)-19(6). Emergency exceptions under Art 358, 359. Immunities under Art 361. Preventive detention Art 22. Armed Forces Art 33.

overview: **Art 19(2) to 19(6)** allow State to impose **reasonable restrictions**
Only on **specified grounds** (cannot be on any arbitrary ground)
art19_1a_SpeechExpression: **Restrictions** (Art 19(2)): Sovereignty & integrity of India, security of State, friendly relations with foreign states, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, incitement to offence
**Examples**: Censorship during war, ban on hate speech, obscenity laws, sedition
art19_1b_Assembly: **Restrictions** (Art 19(3)): Sovereignty & integrity of India, public order
**Examples**: Section 144 CrPC (prohibit assembly), ban on unlawful assemblies
art19_1c_Association: **Restrictions** (Art 19(4)): Sovereignty & integrity of India, public order, morality
**Examples**: Ban on organizations (RSS banned 1948-49, CPI banned in past)
art19_1d_Movement: **Restrictions** (Art 19(5)): Interests of general public, protection of Scheduled Tribes
**Examples**: Inner Line Permit in NE states, restricted areas for security
art19_1e_Residence: **Freedom**: Reside and settle in any part of India (19(1)(e))
**Restrictions** (Art 19(5)): Interests of general public, protection of Scheduled Tribes
**Examples**: J&K had Art 35A restrictions (abrogated 2019), tribal area protections
art19_1g_Profession: **Freedom**: Practice any profession, occupation, trade, business (19(1)(g))
**Examples**: Professional qualifications required, licenses for trades, nationalization of industries
reasonablenessTest: **Proportionality**: Restriction must be proportionate to objective
**Least restrictive**: Should not go beyond necessity
**Not arbitrary**: Must have rational nexus with objective
**Examples**: Total ban may be unreasonable; licensing may be reasonable
content.examTips: **Most asked**: Grounds for restrictions on each freedom. **Art 19(1)(a)** has **8 grounds** (most); **19(1)(g)** has **1 ground** (least). Reasonableness decided by **courts**. Remember: 'Sovereignty & integrity' added by 16th Amendment 1963 (after China war).

overview: **Preventive detention** = Detention to **prevent future crime** (not punishment for past crime)
exceptions: **Art 22(3)**: Safeguards in Art 22(1)-(2) **do not apply** to preventive detention
No right to be informed of grounds immediately (grounds communicated later)
No right to consult lawyer immediately
No right to be produced before magistrate within 24 hours
safeguards: **Art 22(4)**: Detention beyond **3 months** requires **Advisory Board** approval
**Art 22(5)**: Grounds of detention must be communicated **as soon as possible**; detenu can make representation
**Art 22(6)**: Detention beyond Advisory Board opinion period requires fresh order
**Art 22(7)**: Parliament can prescribe circumstances and procedure by law
**Advisory Board**: Consists of serving or retired High Court judges; gives opinion within 3 months
laws: **National Security Act (NSA) 1980** - Detention up to 12 months
**Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act (COFEPOSA) 1974**
**Prevention of Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act (PITNDPS) 1988**
**Maintenance of Internal Security Act (MISA)** - Repealed in 1978 (misused during Emergency)
criticism: **Low conviction rate**: Most detentions not leading to convictions
content.examTips: **Art 22(3)-(7)**: Preventive detention exception. **3 months** = max detention without Advisory Board. **Advisory Board** has HC judges. Art 22(1)-(2) safeguards **NOT applicable**. Laws: NSA, UAPA, COFEPOSA. MISA repealed 1978 (Emergency misuse).

articles.title: Restriction of FRs for Armed Forces

provision: **Art 33**: Parliament can **restrict or abrogate** FRs for members of Armed Forces, para-military forces, police
Covers: Army, Navy, Air Force, para-military forces (BSF, CRPF, CISF, ITBP, SSB), police forces
rationale: **Military discipline** requires restrictions on certain freedoms
Cannot allow complete freedom of speech (may compromise operations)
Cannot allow right to form associations (no unions in army)
restrictedRights: **No freedom of speech and expression** (19(1)(a)) - Cannot criticize superiors openly
**No right to form associations** (19(1)(c)) - No trade unions in armed forces
**No right to constitutional remedies** (Art 32) - Cannot directly approach SC for service matters (use Armed Forces Tribunal)
**Special laws apply**: Army Act, Navy Act, Air Force Act, Police Acts
laws: **Army Act 1950**, Navy Act 1957, Air Force Act 1950 - Restrict FRs for armed forces
**Armed Forces Tribunal Act 2007** - Exclusive jurisdiction for service matters
**Police Acts** - Restrict FRs for police forces
content.examTips: **Art 33**: Parliament can restrict FRs for **armed forces, para-military, police**. No unions (Art 19(1)(c) restricted). Service matters go to **Armed Forces Tribunal** (not SC under Art 32 directly). Ensures **discipline**.

provision: **Art 34**: Parliament can **indemnify** persons for acts done during **Martial Law**
Protects military/civil personnel from legal action for acts during Martial Law
Does NOT provide for declaration of Martial Law (extra-constitutional concept)
Only deals with **consequences** of Martial Law
martialLaw: **Martial Law** = Military rule replacing civil administration
**Extra-constitutional**: No provision in Constitution to declare it
**Independent India**: NEVER declared (AFSPA used instead for disturbed areas)
indemnity: Parliament can pass law to **protect** persons from prosecution/suits
Validates acts that may have been illegal
Ensures military personnel not harassed by litigation
content.examTips: **Art 34**: **Indemnity** for acts during Martial Law (NOT provision to declare it). Parliament passes law protecting personnel. Martial Law **NEVER declared** in independent India. Use AFSPA in disturbed areas instead.

articles.title: Automatic Suspension of Art 19 during Emergency

provision: Applies only to **war or external aggression** emergency (NOT armed rebellion)
effect: **State can make any law** violating Art 19 (will not be void under Art 13)
**Executive can take any action** violating Art 19 (cannot be challenged)
duration: Acts done during emergency **remain valid** even after emergency (unless specifically repealed)
examples: During 1962 Emergency (China war), 1971 Emergency (Pakistan war): Art 19 suspended
Government could impose censorship, restrict movement, ban organizations without court challenge
content.examTips: **Art 358**: Art 19 **automatically suspended** during National Emergency (war/external aggression only, NOT armed rebellion). NO Presidential order needed. Revives **automatically** when emergency ends. Absolute suspension.

articles.title: Suspension of Other FRs during Emergency

provision: **Art 359**: President can suspend **right to move court** for enforcement of FRs during **National Emergency**
Applies to FRs **other than Art 19** (Art 19 covered by Art 358)
effect: Cannot approach court to enforce FRs mentioned in Presidential order
State can violate those FRs; citizens cannot seek remedy
**Art 20-21 protected**: Right to life, protection against conviction, cannot be suspended
44thAmendment: **Art 20-21 cannot be suspended** even during emergency
**Art 359(1A) added**: Acts during emergency NOT automatically protected; State must act within law
Illegal acts still punishable after emergency
1975Emergency: **ADM Jabalpur case (1976)**: SC held even Art 21 (life) suspended; no HC even for illegal detention
**Justice H.R. Khanna dissented**: Right to life cannot be suspended (he was superseded)
**44th Amendment**: Overruled ADM Jabalpur; Art 20-21 cannot be suspended
content.examTips: **Art 359**: Presidential order required to suspend **enforcement** of FRs (except Art 19 covered by Art 358). **Art 20-21 CANNOT be suspended** (44th Amendment 1978). ADM Jabalpur case overruled. Suspension is of **enforcement**, not rights themselves.

articles.title: Saving of Property Laws & DPSP Laws

article31A: **Art 31A**: Saving of laws providing for acquisition of estates, etc.
Laws for acquisition of estates (zamindari abolition), management of property by State, etc. **cannot be challenged** on ground of violating Art 14, 19, 31
Protects **land reform laws** from judicial review
article31B: **Art 31B**: Validation of certain Acts and Regulations (Ninth Schedule)
Acts/Regulations placed in **Ninth Schedule** cannot be challenged on ground of violating FRs
Originally 13 Acts; now **284 Acts** (misused for non-land reform Acts)
**I.R. Coelho (2007)**: SC held Acts violating **basic structure** can be reviewed even if in 9th Schedule
article31C: **Art 31C**: Saving of laws giving effect to DPSP (Art 39(b), (c))
Laws implementing Art 39(b), 39(c) (socialist DPSPs) cannot be challenged on ground of violating Art 14, 19
**42nd Amendment 1976**: Extended to ALL DPSPs (struck down by SC in Minerva Mills case)
rationale: **Protect land reforms** from being struck down by courts
**DPSP implementation** (non-justiciable principles) given priority over FR (justiciable rights)
Balance between FR (individual rights) and DPSP (social welfare)
criticism: **Undermines judicial review** - core of rule of law
**9th Schedule misused** - Acts unrelated to land reforms placed
**FR vs DPSP conflict** - Which is more important?
**I.R. Coelho judgment**: Restored balance; basic structure cannot be violated
content.examTips: **Art 31A**: Protects land reform laws (1st Amendment 1951). **Art 31B**: 9th Schedule immunity (1st Amendment); I.R. Coelho case limited it (basic structure protected). **Art 31C**: Protects laws implementing Art 39(b), (c) only (originally all DPSPs - struck down by Minerva Mills).

provision: **Art 361(1)**: President/Governors **immune from court proceedings** during term of office
**Criminal immunity**: Absolute during office; no criminal proceedings
**Civil immunity**: Can file civil suit only after **2 months notice**; proceedings stayed during office
**Personal acts**: Immunity covers **official acts** done in official capacity
rationale: Constitutional head needs protection to perform duties
scope: **Covers**: Acts done in official capacity as President/Governor
**Does NOT cover**: Personal acts done before assuming office (can be prosecuted after term)
**After term**: Can be prosecuted for acts done before or after office (not during office)
**Impeachment**: Can be impeached during office (not ordinary criminal trial)
examples: President cannot be arrested or prosecuted during tenure
Governor cannot be sued in personal capacity during tenure
After leaving office, can be prosecuted for pre-office crimes
content.examTips: **Art 361**: President & Governors **immune during office**. Criminal immunity = absolute; Civil suit = after 2 months notice (proceedings stayed). Covers **official acts**. Can be impeached (not ordinary trial). After office, can be prosecuted for pre-office acts.

article358: **Emergency type**: Only during **war or external aggression** (NOT armed rebellion)
**Effect**: Art 19 **completely suspended**; State can make any law/take any action violating Art 19
**Protection**: Acts during emergency remain valid even after
article359: **Scope**: **All FRs except Art 19** (and Art 20-21 after 44th Amendment)
**Emergency type**: During **any National Emergency** (war, external aggression, armed rebellion)
**Effect**: **Right to move court** suspended (not FRs themselves); cannot seek enforcement
keyDifferences: **1. Scope**: Art 358 = Art 19 only; Art 359 = Other FRs
**2. Automatic**: Art 358 = automatic; Art 359 = Presidential order needed
**3. Emergency type**: Art 358 = war/external aggression only; Art 359 = any emergency
**4. Suspension**: Art 358 = complete; Art 359 = enforcement suspended
**5. Protection**: Art 358 = acts valid after emergency; Art 359 = acts not automatically protected (44th Amendment)
content.examTips: **Most asked comparison**. **Art 358** = Art 19, automatic, war/external aggression only, complete suspension. **Art 359** = Other FRs, Presidential order, any emergency, enforcement suspended. Art 20-21 cannot be suspended (44th Amendment).

data.summary: **Exceptions to FRs**: (1) **Reasonable restrictions** on Art 19 (Art 19(2)-(6)), (2) **Preventive detention** (Art 22(3)-(7) - exception to Art 21-22), (3) **Armed forces** (Art 33 - restrict FRs), (4) **Martial Law** (Art 34 - indemnity), (5) **Emergency** (Art 358 - Art 19 suspended automatically during war/external aggression; Art 359 - other FRs suspended by Presidential order), (6) **Saving laws** (Art 31A/B/C - land reforms, 9th Schedule, DPSP laws), (7) **Immunity** (Art 361 - President, Governors immune during office). **44th Amendment 1978**: Art 20-21 cannot be suspended even during Emergency. **I.R. Coelho (2007)**: 9th Schedule Acts violating basic structure can be reviewed.
